  • Simpatico - Simulation Package for Polymer and Molecular Liquids

Capabilities

Potential Energy

All of the Simpatico programs use a potential energy that can contain:

  • nonbonded pair interactions
  • covalent two-body bond, three-body angle and four-body dihedral potentials
  • external one-body potentials

Several different types of potential energy function are provided for the nonbonded pair interaction and for each type of covalent interactions. Others are easily added. To simplify integration of MC and MD simulations, all programs are currently restricted to models with differentiation potentials (i.e., not hard spheres), with no explicit constraints on bond lengths or bond angles. The default version of the program currently includes only non-bonded pair interactions and two-body covalent bond interactions. Other types of interactions can be enabled when the program is compiled by defining corresponding makefile variables.

Source code for classes that represent potential energy functions, which we refer to as "interactions", are all in the src/inter directory, and are all defined in the "Inter" C++ namespace. The same set of such classes is used by the mcSim, mdSim, and ddSim programs.

Long-range electrostatic potentials have not yet been implemented in any of the programs. This is the most important missing feature required to make the package suitable for atomistic models.

Simulation Algorithms

For single-processor MD simulations, mdSim currently provides:

  • NVE velocity Verlet
  • NVT Nose-Hoover
  • NVT dissipative particle dynamics
  • NPH Anderson barostat

For Monte-Carlo simulation, mcSim currently provides the following MC moves, and a few others:

  • Single atom displacement
  • Rigid molecule displacement
  • Hybrid MC moves (short NVE or NPH simulations as proposed MC moves) in NVT and NPT ensembles.
  • Reptation move for linear chains
  • Configuration bias regrowth of all or part of a linear chain.
  • Double rebridging for linear chains.
  • Double rebridging moves for ring polymers.
  • End-swap move for linear heteropolymers (e.g., diblock copolymers)
  • Semi-grand canonical move (for, e.g., homopolymer blends)

For parallel Md simulations, DdSim thus far provides only two integrators:

  • NVE velocity Verlet
  • NVT Nose-Hoover

GPU Acceleration via integration with Hoomd

Simpatico provides an optional module that allows the use of the Hoomd-blue code for MD on the GPU as a fast engine for hybrid MC simulations. In this mode, an instance of Hoomd-blue is used to implement a hybrid MC move within an mcSim simulation. Short NVE (for NVT ensemble) or NPH (for NPT ensembles) MD simulations are carried out on a GPU, while the main loop is implemented on the CPU, as are any other MC moves. Integration with Hoomd-blue provides a dramatic increase in the speed of MD and HMC simulations: We obtain a speed-up by approximately a factor of 30 for for bead-spring polymer melts with repulsive Lennard-Jones (i.e., Weeks-Chandler-Anderson) pair interactions.

Data Analysis

Simpatico is distributed with a collection of classes for statistical analysis, for use with the single-processor mcSim and mdSim programs. These include classes to evaluate:

  • Thermodynamic properties (energies and stress components)
  • Full and partial radial distribution functions (in real space).
  • Structure factors (in coordinate space).
  • Intramolecular correlation functions.
  • Radii of gyration
  • Mean-squared distances between specific atoms in a molecule.
  • Mean-squared displacements for atoms or molecular centers-of-mass.
  • Auto-correlation functions for vector separations of atom pairs.
  • Intermediate scattering (van Hove) function S(k, t) .

All mcSim and mdSim data analysis classes can be used either on-the-fly, during a simulation, or for post-processing of a trajectory file or a sequence of configuration dump files. Postprocessing is done by the the mcSim and mdSim programs, by invoking a command that replaces the main the mcSim or mdSim simulation program, using a command that replaces the main simulation loop by a loop that reads a sequence of configurations from file.

Thus far, very few data analyis and data output classes have been written for use with ddSim. MD trajectories from ddSim simulations can instead by post-processed by using mcSim or msSim as analysis tools.

Simpatico currently provides a very convenient tool for running and analyzing simulations of coarse-grained models of polymer liquids. It is not yet suitable for use with atomistic models, because of the absence of an electrostatic potential, and the absence of MC conformation sampling algorithms designed specifically for use with stiff angle potentials.
